misconceptions.name: Implemented an unrelated acceleration example instead of the required even-number sum
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program that computes average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing the even numbers, indicating a disconnect between the problem specification and the implemented solution.
misconceptions.student_belief: I think this task is to write a program that asks for v0, v1, and t and then prints the average acceleration (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to write a program that reads five integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers. The program should not compute acceleration; it should read exactly five integers (typically with nextInt), use a loop and a conditional (n % 2 == 0) to identify evens, accumulate their sum in an integer variable, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt text says "Enter v0, v1, and t:" instead of asking for five integers.
The program declares double v0, v1, t and reads three doubles instead of five integers.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs; only three values are read directly.
No conditional check (such as n % 2 == 0) is present to filter even numbers.
The program computes acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t and prints "The average acceleration is ..." rather than summing and printing even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused a textbook or lecture example about computing average acceleration without adapting it to the current specification, suggesting they did not carefully interpret or translate the problem statement into program requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start by restating the problem in your own words and outlining the steps before writing any code. For this task: (1) declare an int sum = 0; (2) use a for-loop that runs 5 times; (3) inside the loop, read an int n with nextInt; (4) if (n % 2 == 0) add n to sum; (5) after the loop, print "Sum of even numbers: " + sum. Avoid copying code from unrelated examples unless you deliberately adapt it to the new requirements.
related_concepts: Difference between example code and task-specific code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and prompt match a standard acceleration example and have no overlap with the required behavior (no loop, no even check, no sum), strongly suggesting the student implemented the wrong task rather than making a small mistake.

evidence.note: This code reads three doubles v0, v1, t and computes average acceleration instead of reading five integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Program Implementation: Complete Mismatch to Assignment
misconceptions.description: The submitted code solves an entirely different problem (calculating acceleration based on three double inputs) and fails to implement any of the required logic for finding the sum of five even integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or drastically misunderstood the core objective, believing that calculating acceleration was the goal instead of summing even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be specifically designed to read 5 integer values, ideally using a loop, apply conditional logic (the modulo operator) to check for evenness, and use an accumulator variable to compute the sum.
symptoms: Code calculates a ratio/difference (acceleration) instead of a sum.
Program input reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers.
No use of conditional statements or the modulus operator (%).
Class name and output string relate to acceleration, not summation.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major failure in problem decomposition or submitting the wrong file altogether (an unrelated assignment).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions 'Sum of Even Numbers' carefully. Start by ensuring your program reads the correct number of input values (five) of the correct data type (integers). Separate the tasks: input, looping/filtering, and calculation.
related_concepts: Loops (For or While) for repeated input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code is dedicated to an arithmetic calculation (acceleration) and deviates completely from the required logic (input loop, conditional check, summation).

evidence.note: The class name indicates an entirely different task.
This block reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers and performs acceleration calculation, missing all core assignment requirements.

misconceptions.name: Solving the wrong problem
misconceptions.description: The student has written code to calculate acceleration from physics (reading 3 doubles for v0, v1, and t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers as specified in the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving an acceleration calculation problem, not the sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which ones are even (divisible by 2), and printing their sum.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
Program prompts for v0, v1, t instead of asking for 5 integers
Output is completely different from expected output
misconceptions.root_cause: The student may have copied code from a different assignment or problem without carefully reading the Q1 requirements. This suggests incomplete problem comprehension before starting to code.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully. You need to: (1) use a loop to read 5 integers, (2) check if each integer is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulate the sum of only even numbers, (4) print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is absolutely certain. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) than what is asked (sum of even numbers). No amount of minor interpretation can reconcile these two different problems.

evidence.note: Reading 3 doubles with physics variable names instead of 5 integers

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Calculating and printing acceleration instead of sum of even numbers

misconceptions.name: Program does not implement the required sum-of-even-numbers problem
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones, the program is an average acceleration calculator using three double inputs and a physics formula. This indicates a failure to translate the given problem specification into the correct algorithm and code.
misconceptions.student_belief: As long as my program compiles and performs some numeric calculation with user input, it can be an acceptable answer even if it does not follow the exact problem description.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly implement the specified behavior: prompt for and read exactly five integers, use a conditional to select only the even numbers (e.g., n % 2 == 0), accumulate their sum, and print that sum. Writing an unrelated calculator, such as an acceleration calculator, does not satisfy the problem requirements.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers.
Program reads three double values rather than five integers.
No loop is used to process multiple inputs.
No conditional or modulus operation is used to test for even numbers.
Output message reports 'The average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely copied or adapted a previously seen example (an acceleration calculator) without understanding how to design a new algorithm from the textual specification. This suggests difficulty in mapping problem requirements (sum of 5 even integers) into an appropriate control structure and data flow.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem and first write the steps in plain language: (1) ask the user for 5 integers, (2) for each integer, check if it is even using n % 2 == 0, (3) if it is even, add it to a running total, (4) after all 5 numbers, print the total. Then implement these steps in Java with a loop (for or while), an if-statement, an int accumulator variable, and integer input (nextInt).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every key part of the program (class name, prompt text, variable names, data types, formula, and printed message) aligns with a standard acceleration example rather than with the requested sum-of-even-numbers task, indicating a complete mismatch with the specification.

evidence.note: Entire program is an acceleration calculator: it reads three doubles (v0, v1, t), computes (v1 - v0) / t, and prints an acceleration message, instead of reading 5 integers, checking for even numbers, and summing them.

misconceptions.name: Complete Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for a completely different problem (calculating acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (summing 5 even integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program to calculate average acceleration, or they submitted the incorrect file for this assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly 5 integers, identifying the even ones, and calculating their sum.
symptoms: Code name suggests a kinematic problem ('AccelerationCalculator')
Input prompts ask for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Variables are named 'v0', 'v1', 't', and 'acceleration'
Calculations perform (v1 - v0) / t
Output prints an acceleration message
misconceptions.root_cause: Major error in interpreting the assignment prompt or submitting the wrong code file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Always double-check that the code being written directly addresses all constraints and requirements of the current assignment. Review the problem statement for 'Sum of Even Numbers' and restart the implementation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the submitted code corresponds to a known physics problem (acceleration calculation) and bears zero resemblance to the requested task (sum of 5 even numbers).

evidence.note: The class name indicates a different problem domain.
Prompt asks for variables specific to acceleration calculation (v0, v1, t), not 5 generic integers.
Calculation is for acceleration, not accumulating a sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Number and Type of Inputs
misconceptions.description: The student reads 3 inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of the required 5 inputs, and reads them as doubles instead of integers, which is necessary for checking parity (even/odd).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that only three double values are needed for input (consistent with the acceleration problem).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading 5 distinct numerical inputs, which should be integers, since calculating the sum of *even* numbers is typically done with integers (requiring the modulo operator).
symptoms: Only three Scanner calls instead of five.
Use of input.nextDouble() prevents clean modulo checking required by the parity constraint.
misconceptions.root_cause: The error stems from implementing the wrong program, leading to incorrect input handling matching that program instead of the required one.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: For the assigned task, verify that the program uses a loop or five separate calls to `input.nextInt()` to read exactly five integers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The constraints of the input (5 integers) are completely unmet (3 doubles).

misconceptions.name: Loop requirement misunderstanding for multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The student does not recognize that processing multiple sequential inputs (in this case, 5 integers) requires a loop structure. Instead, the student reads only 3 values using individual statements without iteration.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that they can handle multiple inputs by writing separate input statements, without needing iteration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When reading an arbitrary number of values from the user, a loop (for or while) is essential to avoid code duplication and to scale with input count. For exactly 5 integers, a for-loop from i=0 to i<5 with input.nextInt() inside is the standard approach.
symptoms: Only 3 inputs read instead of 5
No loop structure in code
Each input read with a separate statement
Cannot process the required 5 integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible lack of exposure to or understanding of how loops reduce code duplication and handle repetitive tasks. Student may not recognize the pattern of 'read multiple values' as requiring iteration.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for-loop: for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... } This will read exactly 5 integers without code repetition.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any loop structure and the presence of only 3 hard-coded input statements makes this very clear. This is a fundamental pattern for multi-input processing.

evidence.note: Three separate input.nextDouble() calls with no loop, demonstrating the student reads only 3 values without iteration.

misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for filtering even numbers
misconceptions.description: The student does not implement any conditional check to determine whether a number is even. There is no use of the modulo operator (%) or any if-statement to filter only even numbers before adding to a sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears not to understand that conditional logic is needed to selectively process certain values (even vs. odd) from the input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To find the sum of even numbers, you must check each input number with a condition like (n % 2 == 0). If true, add it to a running sum; if false, skip it. This requires an if-statement inside the input-reading loop.
symptoms: No modulo operator used
No if-statement to check even/odd
No accumulator conditional logic
Output is unrelated to even number filtering
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not be familiar with the modulo operator for divisibility checks, or may not understand that filtering data requires conditional branching before accumulation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside the input loop, add: if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; } This checks if the remainder when divided by 2 is 0 (even) before adding.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional logic whatsoever. The calculation performed (acceleration) involves no filtering step. This is a critical missing component of the required solution.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

        System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The entire computation is arithmetic with no conditional check for even numbers. The formula has no filtering logic.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect data type selection (double vs. int)
misconceptions.description: The student reads input as double using nextDouble() instead of reading integers using nextInt(). The problem explicitly specifies reading integers, but the student used floating-point type.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that double is an appropriate type for reading the user input, possibly not recognizing that the problem requires integer processing.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifies reading integers, use the int data type and input.nextInt(). Doubles (floating-point numbers) are used only when decimal values are needed. Using doubles here causes type mismatch with the problem requirements and the modulo operator (% works on integers, not doubles).
symptoms: Use of nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
Variables declared as double instead of int
Type mismatch with integer-based operations like modulo
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not understand the distinction between integer and floating-point types, or may not have carefully read the problem statement which specifies integers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change all input reading to: int num = input.nextInt(); and use int for all variables storing the input numbers.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The problem clearly states 'reads 5 integers' but code uses double and nextDouble(). This type choice is incompatible with the even-number check (requires modulo on integers).

evidence.note: All inputs are read as double using nextDouble(), when the problem requires reading integers with nextInt().
